_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary:

Airgas USA, LLC., an Air Liquide Company, commonly referred to as Airgas Merchant Gases(AMG) leases an industrial property located at 8801 Helms Avenue Rancho Cucamonga, CA.  Hydrogen Distribution Services, also an Air Liquide Company, commonly referred to as (HDS) operates a tractor trailer terminal at this location.  Various trailer sizes and styles contain liquified and or gaseous hydrogen.  Because HDS operates this terminal location with hydrogen, a Regulated Substance over the Threshold Quantity of 10,000 pounds, and stores, handles, and controls the on-site movement of this Regulated Substance; this HDS terminal location is subject to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA's) Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions, Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations, Part 68 (40 CFR Part 68)  as well as the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) program under California's Code of Regulations Title 19.  CalARP includes some additional state requirements and is implemented at the local government level by the Certified Unified Program Agencies (CUPA's) which determine the level of detail in the RMPs, review RMPs, conduct facility inspections and provide public access to RMP information. The San Bernardino County Fire Department (CUPA) is the implementing agency for the HDS South Terminal covered process. HDS and Airgas' commitment to safety and environmental protection extends beyond its gates. As part of the community, we have a responsibility to our customers and to those who live in the surrounding area.

Regulated Chemical and Covered Process:

HDS operates Department of Transportation (DOT) certified mobile tractors and tanker trailers. HDS tractors transport liquid and/or gaseous hydrogen trailers to and from the South Terminal Facility. It is possible that full or partially filled trailers will be parked at the terminal for twenty-four hours or a longer period.  HDS provides cryogenic liquid hydrogen (LH2) UN 1966,

CAS number 1333-74-0, to mobile fuel market customers in California. Liquid hydrogen (LH2) will arrive at the facility in jumbo trailers or short trailers.  HDS will also provide gaseous hydrogen (GH2) to customers in California. The gaseous hydrogen, UN1049, CAS number 1333-74-0, will arrive at the facility in 450 Bar trailers. When a liquid hydrogen trailers or gaseous hydrogen tube trailers arrive, they will be parked in designated locations and the motive tractor disconnected and separately parked in identified positions.

General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps:

The highly flammable and hazardous nature of hydrogen in the process makes it necessary for HDS to observe certain safety precautions to prevent unnecessary human and environmental exposure and to reduce the potential threat to personnel and nearby members of the community.  HDS' policy is to comply with all applicable federal and state rules and regulations. This Executive Summary sets forth some of the management systems in place to implement the accidental release and prevention program. HDS has also implemented specific chemical prevention steps to help prevent potential scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures and human errors. The following examples of the types of safety features in place: (1) Release Mitigation - Emergency stop buttons to isolate hydrogen sources; personal protective equipment (personal gas detectors, protective outerwear clothing, intrinsically safe devices, safety goggles, shoes, etc.) (2) System Integrity - Automatic control and manual valves that provides isolation for hydrogen vessels from hydrogen equipment located in the trailers control cabinet.  Pressure Safety Valves and Thermal Pressure Relief Devices are located on the various hydrogen vessels. (3) Facility and Environment - Contracted emergency response specialist, Safety-Kleen, to support the HDS South Terminal emergency response plan.

Employee Partic

ipation (EP)

HDS has developed a written plan of action and South Terminal employee/operators are expected to participate in the accidental release prevention program (RMP/PSM). Employees are trained on and provided access to the hydrogen process safety information. Specific actions an employee can be involved in the accident prevention program are documented in the Employee Participation plan. Forms of participation include being part of a PHA, a PSSR, and/or being involved in incident investigation.  Employees participate in monthly safety meetings where process safety issues are discussed and corrective actions are developed, and they are involved in the review of the covered process operating procedures annually to ensure they remain current, accurate and recommend any necessary changes.

Process Safety Information (PSI)

HDS keeps a variety of technical documents onsite and in the company's electronic document control system that are used to help maintain safe operation of its processes. These documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, equipment design/configuration information, specific chemical inventories and operation limits for key process parameters - all key information for operating the process safely.  Process operators are trained to operate the process using process controls and instrumentation within these safe operating limits.  The Terminal Manager is responsible for maintaining up-to-date process safety information. A table summarizing the reference documents and their location is readily accessible as part of the written employee participation.

Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)

HDS/Airgas has a risk management program to help ensure that hazards associated with the various processes are identified and controlled. The covered process underwent an initial process hazard analysis (PHA) and will continue to undergo periodic review/re-validations at least every five years or as required by Management Of Change (MOC). The P

HA team consists of members with the appropriate experience to define the hazards and mitigating controls of the process and also represents a cross-section of the employees working in the process. For future PHA reviews, local and corporate management will review the PHA team findings and develop a resolution action plan for each item, which will be documented, tracked and ultimately closed in the Airgas action item database tracking system. Facility Manager is responsible for prioritizing and tracking implementation of the action plan to closure.

Operating Procedures (OP)

HDS/Airgas maintains controlled written procedures that address various modes of liquefied and gaseous hydrogen process operations, such as: (1) initial startup; (2) normal operations; (3) emergency shutdown; (4) normal shutdown and; (5) startup after turnaround or emergency shutdown. The hydrogen transfer operation will not operate under temporary or emergency operations. If these conditions occur, plant operators and management will evaluate the circumstances and either shut the plant down or complete an MOC, including and emergency MOC. Additionally, the emergency shutdown procedure includes conditions that will prompt a shutdown and identifies qualified and
responsible operators to complete the steps in a safe and timely manner.  Airgas operating procedures have safe operating limits identified along with consequences of unsafe deviation. Procedures further provide steps for operators to take that will correct or avoid an unsafe
deviation. Airgas procedures are used by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators. These procedures are reviewed and annually certified as current and accurate.

Training (TRN)

HDS South Terminal has implemented a training program for all employee/operators involved in the hydrogen covered process. All employees receive a combination of classroom, computer-based (CBT) and hands-on training that addresses such topi

cs as: general orientation, facility rules and practices, process safety information, normal and emergency operating procedures, health and safety consideration, use of safety procedures and equipment, incident investigation and emergency response. In addition, all operators are required to attend refresher training at least every three years. Training is documented and tracked in a local facility matrix and electronically in the Airgas University training system.

Mechanical Integrity (MI)

HDS South Terminal has established mechanical integrity (MI) practices and procedures, based on preventative maintenance, to maintain pressure vessels, and equipment on the hydrogen trailers such as piping systems, relief valves and vent systems, controls and interlocks, pumps and emergency shutdown systems in a safe operating condition. The basic aspects of this program include: (1) conducting training, (2) developing written procedures, (3) performing inspections and tests; (4) correcting identified deficiencies, and (5) applying quality assurance measures. In combination, these written activities form a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of the process equipment. The MI program assists with the verification and suitability of new and existing process equipment and, as well as quality control of spare parts and modifications to existing process equipment.

Management of Change (MOC)

Airgas' management of change (MOC) procedure has established requirements for ensuring proposed process or equipment changes or changes indirectly affecting processes are evaluated, approved and documented prior to implementation through the use of a management of change process. The MOC procedure outlines the requirements for documenting, evaluating the impact, and approving planned deviations from procedure. All MOC's are submitted, reviewed by subject matter specialist (such as Engineering, Risk Management, Operations, Health and Safety), approved, tracked and closed using a

n electronic approval and tracking system. Upon closure, personnel whose assigned job functions are impacted by the MOC, are briefed and /or trained in the MOC requirements.

Pre-startup Safety Reviews (PSSR)

HDS South Terminal ensures the safety of new/modified facilities or processes before placing those facilities or processes into service through the use of pre-startup safety reviews (PSSR's). PSSR's are intended to ensure safety through confirmation that: (1) construction and equipment are in accordance with design specifications; (2) safety, operating, maintenance and emergency procedures are in place and adequate; (3) PHA's have been performed and recommendations resolved before startup of new plants or processes; (4) MOC requirements have been satisfied for modified facilities; and (5) training has been completed and documented for affected operator/employees.

Compliance Audits (CA)

To help ensure the accident prevention program is functioning properly, Airgas Merchant Gases conducts an audit to determine whether the procedures and practices required by the accidental release prevention program are being implemented at this HDS South Terminal facility. Compliance audits are conducted at least every three years.  Resolutions to recommendations are documented, tracked and closed. Once the resolutions have been completed, changes are communicated to operating, maintenance and other employees whose work assignments are in the covered process and who may be affected by the recommendations or actions. Training and communication is documented.

Incident Investigation (II):

HDS South Terminal defines management systems and establishes the requirements for communicating, investigating and reporting of incidents at all facilities through the use of an Incident Investigation and reporting procedure. Airgas documents incident and subsequent investigation, follow up actions, and closure in an electronic document control system. The Facility Manager/HSEQ i

s responsible for maintaining a log and tracking incidents and corrective actions through completion.  Results of findings and corrective actions are shared with employee/operators who could be affected by the findings. Reports are retained for at least five years to be reviewed during future PHA's and revalidation actions.

Safe & Hot Work Permit System (HWP):

HDS South Terminal has a safe & hot work permit process in place to help ensure worker and process safety. This system is comprised of a group of corporate procedures, standards and forms under the life safety program. Procedures in place include: (1) energy control; (2) safe work; (3) hot work and; (4) confined space entry. HDS South Terminal associates are trained on these safe work practices to ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed professionally and safely.

Contractors (CON):

HDS South Terminal uses contractors to supplement its own workforce when maintenance activities exceed the capabilities or time available for their own employee/operators. Contractors are made aware of the potential dangers involved with a hydrogen covered process under PSM/RMP and CalARP. Procedures are in place to make sure that contractors: (1) perform their work in a safe manner, (2) have the appropriate knowledge and skills, (3) are aware of the hazards in their workplace, and (4) understand what they should do in the event of an emergency, prior to their beginning work. Periodically contractors are evaluated to ensure that both their safety performance and training required for work on the covered hydrogen system meets the HDS South Terminal safety standards.

Five-Year Accident History (AH):

The HDS South Terminal has had no accident resulting in either on or offsite effects in the last five (5) years for the covered hydrogen process.

Emergency Response Program Information (ERP/EAP):

The HDS South Terminal is a non-responding facility and has developed a written Emergency Action

Plan (EAC). The plan outlines action to be taken at the HDS South Terminal for handling small releases, and if larger the communication to emergency responders, local response agencies, and outside agency notification procedures in the event of a hydrogen release. The emergency plan provides for the evacuation of HDS South Terminal personnel, contractors and visitors. The HDS South Terminal has provided their emergency response plan to and coordinates the plan annually with the local Rancho Cucamonga Fire Department, part of the San Bernardino County Fire Department (CUPA). Should an emergency involving the release of hydrogen occur that will have off-site consequences HDS South Terminal management will contact the Rancho Cucamonga Fire Department and local support authorities, who will coordinate action for the affected community.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety:

Safety is an inherent part of the culture at the HDS South Terminal and enhancements in safety and operations are actively discussed and supported. The HDS South Terminal continues to review its processes for possibilities of improvement to the covered hydrogen process, operational methods, and new technology to lower risk. In conclusion of our most recent Process Hazard Analysis (PHA), the HDS South Terminal plans to:
(1) Add Glad Hand locks to isolate quarantined trailers from connection to a tractor while parked at the South Terminal
(2) Signage to indicate hazardous and restricted areas of operation  
(3) Camera installation to monitor the HDS South Terminal for safety and security purposes.
